Lesson 7: Continous Tense and Full A1 Revision

This lesson brings together everything you've learned in Lessons 1 to 6. Let's revise each topic with helpful notes and examples.

🕒 Bonus: Continuous Tense in German

In German, there is no separate continuous tense like in English.

That means instead of saying:

  • I am playing → ❌
  • She is eating → ❌

You just use the present tense directly:

  • Ich spiele – I play / I am playing
  • Sie isst – She eats / She is eating

This works the same in future continuous too:

  • I will be playing cricket → Ich werde Cricket spielen
  • They will be eating → Sie werden essen

✅ So when you learn present and future tense in German, you are already learning continuous tense too!

📘 Lesson 1: Verb Conjugation (trinken)

We learned how to conjugate regular verbs using a clear pattern: remove -en and add the right ending for each pronoun.

Let’s use the verb trinken (to drink):

  • ich trinke → trinken -en + e = ich trinke
  • du trinkst → trinken -en + st = du trinkst
  • er trinkt → trinken -en + t = er trinkt
  • wir trinken → no change = wir trinken
  • sie trinken → no change = sie trinken

This pattern works for most regular verbs like spielen, lernen, singen etc.

🔢 Lesson 3: Numbers and Number Rules

We covered numbers up to 1000 and patterns:

  • 13–19: drei + zehn = dreizehn
  • 21–99: reverse with 'und' → einundzwanzig
  • 30, 40, 50...: use -zig → dreißig, vierzig
  • 100+: combine → einhundert, einhundertfünf
  • 1000+: eintausend

Tip: Break the number into parts and say it in reverse order.

👋 Lesson 4: Introducing Yourself

We built sentences to talk about our name, age, country, language, and hobbies.

  • Ich bin Rahul – I am Rahul
  • Ich bin 20 Jahre alt – I am 20 years old
  • Ich wohne in Berlin – I live in Berlin
  • Ich komme aus Indien – I come from India
  • Ich spreche Englisch und Deutsch – I speak English and German
  • Mein Hobby ist Fußball spielen – My hobby is playing football

This lesson helped you build your first German conversation!

🧍 Lesson 5: Verbs haben and sein

These are two essential irregular verbs:

haben (to have):

  • ich habe
  • du hast
  • er hat
  • wir haben
  • sie haben

sein (to be):

  • ich bin
  • du bist
  • er ist
  • wir sind
  • sie sind

Examples:

  • Ich habe Milch – I have milk
  • Du bist Student – You are a student

These verbs are used every day in real conversations.

🛠️ Lesson 6: Modal Verbs

Modal verbs change like regular verbs, but the second verb goes to the end in infinitive form.

Common modal verbs:

  • können – can → Ich kann lesen
  • wollen – want to → Wir wollen spielen
  • müssen – must → Du musst arbeiten
  • sollen – should → Sie sollen schlafen
  • dürfen – may → Er darf essen

Only one verb (the modal) changes. The second verb always stays in infinitive.

⏳ Future Tense with werden

The future tense in German follows the same structure as modal verbs.

  • ich werde
  • du wirst
  • er wird
  • wir werden
  • sie werden

The main verb stays in infinitive at the end:

  • Ich werde lernen – I will learn
  • Du wirst spielen – You will play
  • Wir werden essen – We will eat

Just like modal verbs, werden is the only verb that changes.

🎉 Excellent! You've completed a full revision of your A1 foundations: pronouns, verbs, self-intro, numbers, modal verbs, and future tense. You’re ready to build real conversations in German.
